summary: This is a letter from defense attorney Jeffrey S. Pagliuca to an Assistant United States Attorney regarding the use of sealed discovery materials in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The letter objects to the government's confidential designation of certain 'Unsealing Materials' and requests permission to use them in related civil litigation and an appeal before Judge Preska and the Second Circuit.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Author of the letter, representing Ghislaine Maxwell's interests, objecting to the government's confidential designation of discovery materials and requesting their use in related litigation.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the criminal case and related civil litigation; the letter concerns discovery materials from cases where she was named a defendant.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the criminal case; the letter indicates intent to seek her permission to use the discovery materials and references a Protective Order she entered.

persons.name: Judge Preska
persons.context: Presiding judge in the related civil case (No. 15 Civ. 7433); the letter discusses an unsealing protocol process before her and a related appeal.

connections.description: Pagliuca is writing as defense counsel, representing Maxwell's legal interests regarding the use of discovery materials.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case and entered the Protective Order referenced in the letter.
Judge Preska is overseeing a related civil case and an unsealing protocol involving materials from cases where Maxwell was a defendant.

events.title: Government Designates Materials Confidential
events.description: The Assistant U.S. Attorney sent a letter to defense counsel designating the 'Unsealing Materials' as Confidential.

events.title: Deadline for Meeting on Unsealing Protocol
events.description: Judge Preska ordered parties in the related civil case to meet regarding modifications to the unsealing protocol by this date.

locations: The Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit
keyFacts: The letter reveals ongoing legal disputes about sealing and public access to discovery materials in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.
It references 'Unsealing Materials' which are ex parte government pleadings, hearing transcripts, and rulings from settled civil cases involving Maxwell.
The defense argues these materials are judicial documents with a presumptive right of public access and objects to their confidential designation.
The letter indicates coordination between multiple courts: Judge Nathan's criminal case, Judge Preska's civil case, and the Second Circuit Court of Appeals.
A law firm, Boies, Schiller & Flexner, is identified as being aware of the sealed materials due to their cooperation with the government.
